Quantum Computing Explained

item.title: IoT devices are an enterprise security time bomb | ZDNet
item.description:
IoT devices are an enterprise security time bomb | ZDNet

The Internet of Things (IoT) is causing serious security concerns for enterprises worldwide with few companies capable of securing them as they are unable to identify devices properly, according to new research. On Wednesday, ForeScout Technologies revealed the results of a new survey into the challenges IoT poses for the enterprise.

item.title: IBM Can Run an Experimental AI in Memory, Not on Processors
item.description:
IBM Can Run an Experimental AI in Memory, Not on Processors

Don't throw out your CPUs just yet, but there may be a new way to run your neural networks. In the regular world of computing-whether you're running exotic deep learning algorithms or just using Excel-calculations are usually performed on a processor while data is passed back and forth to the memory.

item.title: Yann LeCun - How does the brain learn so much so quickly? (CCN 2017)
Blockchains: How They Work and Why They'll Change the World
item.description:
Blockchains: How They Work and Why They'll Change the World

Jump to Sections in this Feature Bitcoin was hatched as an act of defiance. Unleashed in the wake of the Great Recession, the cryptocurrency was touted by its early champions as an antidote to the inequities and corruption of the traditional financial system.

item.title: Blockchain Protocol Analysis and Security Engineering 2017 | Cyber Initiative
item.description:
Blockchain Protocol Analysis and Security Engineering 2017 | Cyber Initiative

January 26-27 2017, Paul Brest Hall, Stanford University Video recordings and slides, where provided by presenters, are posted with talk titles below. The conference will explore the use of formal methods, empirical analysis, and risk modeling to better understand security and systemic risk in blockchain protocols.

item.title: Billions of Devices Potentially Exposed to New Bluetooth Attack | SecurityWeek.Com
item.description:
Billions of Devices Potentially Exposed to New Bluetooth Attack | SecurityWeek.Com

Billions of Android, iOS, Windows and Linux devices that use Bluetooth may be exposed to a new attack that can be carried out remotely without any user interaction, researchers warned. Armis Labs, a company that specializes in protecting Internet of Things (IoT) devices, has discovered a total of eight Bluetooth implementation vulnerabilities that expose mobile, desktop and IoT systems to an attack it has dubbed "BlueBorne."

item.title: Reshaping Business With Artificial Intelligence
item.description:
Reshaping Business With Artificial Intelligence

Advertisement Expectations for artificial intelligence (AI) are sky-high, but what are businesses actually doing now? The goal of this report is to present a realistic baseline that allows companies to compare their AI ambitions and efforts.

item.title: Hackers Can Silently Control Siri, Alexa & Other Voice Assistants Using Ultrasound
item.description:
Hackers Can Silently Control Siri, Alexa & Other Voice Assistants Using Ultrasound

What if your smartphone starts making calls, sending text messages, and browsing malicious websites on the Internet itself without even asking you? This is no imaginations, as hackers can make this possible using your smartphone's personal assistant like Siri or Google Now.

item.title: The Internet Of Things' Massive Security Problem, Visualized
item.description:
The Internet Of Things' Massive Security Problem, Visualized

Earlier this year, the usernames and passwords for more than 8,000 internet of things devices were posted online so hackers could easily access them. The security breach was a perfect illustration of the IoT's security problems: Of the 8,000+ username and password combinations, only 142 were unique.
